nodes.name:
Poultry
Producer
nodes.tooltip: PROBLEM: High operational costs, labor-intensive litter management, disease risk from accumulated waste, and ammonia buildup affecting bird health and worker safety.

nodes.name:
Processing
Plant
nodes.tooltip: PROBLEM: High energy consumption, significant GHG emissions, costly waste disposal for fats/oils/greases, and limited waste-to-value conversion.

nodes.name: Farms
nodes.tooltip: PROBLEM: Over-reliance on chemical fertilizers, nutrient runoff causing water pollution, soil degradation, high diesel consumption, and GHG emissions from synthetic inputs.

nodes.name: Waterways
nodes.tooltip: PROBLEM: Receiving excess nutrients from farm runoff causing algal blooms, fish kills, dead zones, and ecosystem damage. Phosphorus and nitrogen pollution threatens drinking water quality.

nodes.name:
Fresh Poultry
Bedding
nodes.tooltip: PROBLEM: Continuous expense for new pine shavings, supply chain dependency, transportation costs, and no value recovery from used bedding.

nodes.name: Labor
nodes.tooltip: PROBLEM: High labor costs for manual litter removal (every 6-8 weeks), worker exposure to ammonia and dust, labor shortages in agricultural sector.

nodes.name:
Chicken Feed
and Water
nodes.tooltip: PROBLEM: Feed represents 60-70% of production costs, volatile grain prices, water scarcity concerns, and limited circular economy integration.

nodes.name: Energy
nodes.tooltip: PROBLEM: Heavy reliance on grid electricity and fossil fuels, high energy costs, vulnerability to price fluctuations, and carbon footprint from non-renewable sources.

nodes.name: Diesel
nodes.tooltip: PROBLEM: Fossil fuel dependency for farm equipment, volatile fuel prices, direct GHG emissions, and no pathway to renewable alternatives in current system.

nodes.name:
Chemical
Fertilizer
nodes.tooltip: PROBLEM: Expensive synthetic fertilizers, energy-intensive production (natural gas), soil microbiome damage, groundwater contamination, and nutrient runoff causing eutrophication.

nodes.name: Water
nodes.tooltip: PROBLEM: High irrigation demands, aquifer depletion, water scarcity in drought-prone regions, and competition with municipal/industrial water needs.

nodes.name: Meat
nodes.tooltip: OUTPUT: Primary product - chicken meat for human consumption. Challenge is reducing environmental footprint while maintaining production efficiency.

nodes.name:
Fats Oils
Greases
nodes.tooltip: PROBLEM: Waste disposal costs, can clog municipal sewers, limited value recovery, and potential for conversion to biofuels not being utilized.

nodes.name:
Dead
Birds
nodes.tooltip: PROBLEM: 3-5% mortality rate represents economic loss, biosecurity concerns, disposal costs and regulations, and missed opportunity for nutrient recovery.

nodes.name: GHG
nodes.tooltip: PROBLEM: Significant CO2 and methane emissions from processing operations contributing to climate change. No carbon capture or offset mechanisms in place.

nodes.name:
GHG
Emissions
nodes.tooltip: PROBLEM: N2O from fertilizer application (298x more potent than CO2), methane from decomposing litter, and CO2 from diesel equipment. Major contributor to agricultural emissions.

nodes.name: Crops
nodes.tooltip: OUTPUT: Crops grown using chemical fertilizers. Lower soil health over time, vulnerable to drought, and contributing to nutrient runoff issues.

links.label: Fresh Bedding
links.tooltip: PROBLEM: Continuous cost burden - bedding must be replaced every 6-8 weeks with no value recovery from used material.

links.label: Labor
links.tooltip: PROBLEM: Labor-intensive litter management requires frequent cleanouts, exposing workers to ammonia and pathogens.

links.label: Feed & Water
links.tooltip: PROBLEM: Feed costs represent 60-70% of production expenses with volatile commodity prices and limited local sourcing.

links.label: Live Birds
links.tooltip: Live birds transported to processing plant. Transportation stress can affect meat quality and represents biosecurity risk.

links.label: Dead Birds
links.tooltip: PROBLEM: Mortality represents direct economic loss. Carcass disposal is costly and nutrients/energy are wasted instead of recovered.

links.label: Waste Litter
links.tooltip: PROBLEM: Raw litter applied directly to fields causes nutrient overloading, pathogen spread, and excessive phosphorus accumulation in soil.

links.label: Energy
links.tooltip: PROBLEM: High electricity consumption from non-renewable sources, contributing to operational costs and carbon footprint.

links.label: Meat Products
links.tooltip: Primary product output. Environmental footprint per kg of meat is higher than necessary due to inefficient waste management.

links.label: FOG
links.tooltip: PROBLEM: Fats, oils, and greases disposed as waste rather than converted to renewable biofuels. Disposal costs and environmental liability.

links.label: GHG Emissions
links.tooltip: PROBLEM: Unmitigated greenhouse gas emissions from energy use and processing operations. No carbon capture or offset strategy.

links.label: Diesel
links.tooltip: PROBLEM: Fossil fuel dependency for tractors and equipment. Direct GHG emissions and exposure to volatile fuel prices.

links.label: Fertilizer
links.tooltip: PROBLEM: Synthetic fertilizers are costly, energy-intensive to produce, damage soil health, and much of the nutrients run off into waterways.

links.label: Water
links.tooltip: PROBLEM: High irrigation demands deplete aquifers. Chemically-treated soil has poor water retention, requiring more irrigation.

links.label: Crops
links.tooltip: Crop yields dependent on synthetic inputs. Soil degradation over time reduces productivity and increases input requirements.

links.label: GHG Emissions
links.tooltip: PROBLEM: N2O emissions from synthetic fertilizers (298x warming potential vs CO2), plus methane from raw litter decomposition.

links.label: Nutrient Runoff
links.tooltip: CRITICAL PROBLEM: Excess nitrogen and phosphorus runoff causes algal blooms, hypoxic dead zones, fish kills, and drinking water contamination.

links.label: Crops to Feed
links.tooltip: Circular flow: crops become chicken feed. However, nutrient losses through runoff and GHG emissions make this cycle inefficient.
